title: How to fix a 'broken' falsetto - Quora

response.answer_text: I hate to answer a question with a question, but… here goes: What is a “broken” falsetto? I mean, what do you mean by this? It’s not exactly standard singers terminology (at least, not to me, or any of the sources I’ve checked), so I’ll be glad to edit/update this pretty unhelpful answer if you can give some more details. Also, throw in an audio or YouTube example if possible so we can hear what your issue is. In general, you can find lots of help in Richard Miller’s seminal work (and seminally priced) The Structure of Singing or in James McKinney’s competitively priced (and sized) The Diagnosis and Correction of Vocal Faults. I would like to ask this: what is your purpose in singing in falsetto? Don’t read anything into the question; I have no agenda for or against falsetto in asking it. I’m simply curious as to how its use fits in your singing technic. If your technic is wrong, this may be what’s breaking your falsetto. If you have otherwise good technic, your falsetto issues may indicate a physical deformity in the vocal ligaments themselves. You might need to have an otolaryngologist have a look at your cords to be sure they’re smooth and uniform.
